src.models package¶

src.models.predict_model module¶

class src.models.predict_model.Inferer(city_name: str, pollutant: str = 'PM2.5', split_list=[0.7, 0.3])[source]¶

Bases: object

Inferer object is in charge of predicting and infering from previous training data.

Required a trained model.

Parameters

  • city_name – lower case of city name

  • pollutant – str=’PM2.5’

  • split_list (optional) –

dataset¶
Raises

AssertionError – if the city_name is not in city_names list

Sample the possible test data from train data. Add as data_samples attribute

Parameters

Args – n_samples: number of sample per hours step: if not 1, skip some data to make the draw faster day_err hour_err

Calculate the training and seasonal error. Add trn_error and seasonal_error as attribute

compare_inf_act(q_list=[0.75])[source]¶

Compare inference and actual data. Save the results plot.

Parameters

q_list (optional) – a list of inference quantile[defaul=[0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95]]

features_effect_season(features: list, q, ax, red_list=[0, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9], save=False)[source]¶

Show an effect of reducing feature or features on the seasonal patterns

Parameters

  • features – a list of feature to observe

  • q – quantile for picking the inference distribution [default:0.75]

  • red_list – a list of reducting

features_effect_sum(features_list, q, red_list=[0, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9], time_range=[0, - 1], agg='mean', raw_filename=None)[source]¶

Summarize effect of reduction in red_list of the features in the feature list.

Calculate the summary value between time_range and use aggegration method specified by agg :param features_list: :param q: :param red_list: :param agg: :param raw_filename: use when wannting to export the raw plot to csv

Return: pd.DataFrame.

The average prediction pollution level if reduction of each feature occure

src.models.predict_model._reduct_effect_q(model, data_samples, features, sea_error, q, per_cut)[source]¶

Calculate the reduction effect of a single q value.

Convert to seasonal pattern

Parameters

  • model – model for prediction

  • data_samples – weather and fire data

  • features – a list of features to reduce

  • sea_error – correction factor by dayofyear

  • q – quantile value to sample from

Returns: seasonal pattern dataframe

src.models.predict_model.add_lag(df, lag_dict)[source]¶

Build the lag data using number in lag_range. Add the new data as self.data attribute.

Parameters

  • df – dataframe to build lag

  • lag_dict – a dictionary containing laging information such n_max, ‘step’, ‘roll’

Returns: dataframe containing original data and lags

src.models.predict_model.cal_error(dataset, model, data_index)[source]¶

Calculate model performance over training and test dataset.

  • take the daily average and plot actual vs prediction for training and test set

return xtrn, ytrn, xtest, ytext in dataframe format

Parameters

  • dataset – dataset object

  • model – fitted model

  • split_list (optional) – train/test spliting ratio[default:[0.7,0.3]]

  • xlim (optional) – if passed, use these value for xlim

  • filename (optional) – if not None, save the figure using the filename

Returns

actual, prediction of the training set (no averaging) test_pred_df: actual, prediction of the test set (no averaging)

Return type

trn_pred_df

src.models.predict_model.cal_season_band(band_df, sea_error)[source]¶

Convert daily prediction to seasonal prediction

Parameters

  • band_df – daily prediction value after rolling average

  • sea_error – seasonal prediction error

Returns: pd.DataFrame

seasonal prediction with error corrected

src.models.predict_model.get_data_samples(dataset, time_range=[], n_samples=100, step=1, day_err=10, hour_err=2)[source]¶

Sample the possible test data from train dataset. The dataset must alredy has the lag columns built

Parameters

  • dataset – load data using load_model1 function

  • time_range – time range for inference

  • n_samples – number of sample per hours

  • step – if not 1, skip some data to make the draw faster

  • day_err –

  • hour_err –

Return pd.DataFame

sample of weather and fire conditon for each hour. Each hour will have n_samples of data

src.models.predict_model.get_sample(test_datetime, wea, fire, year_list, year_samples, day_err=7, hour_err=2)[source]¶

Randomsamples weather and fire data from previous years around the same dayofyear

Parameters

  • test_datetime – datetime for sampling from the train data

  • wea – weather dataframe from training data

  • fire – fire data df from training data

  • year_list – a list of years in training data

  • year_samples – a list of sample from each year

  • day_error – plus/minus date range to sample from

  • hour_err – plus/minus hour to sample from

Returns

sample dataframe

Return type

data_samples

src.models.predict_model.make_senario(model, data_samples, features, per_cut)[source]¶

Make prediction of the data sample with some feature value reduced.

Parameters

  • model – model for prediction

  • data_samples – test data sample for different data

  • features – columns to cut down

  • per_cut – percent reduction must be between 0 - 1

  • x_cols – x_columns to use for the model

Returns: pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame

ypred_df: predicted value for calculate band

src.models.train_model module¶

src.models.train_model.do_rf_search(x_trn: numpy.array, y_trn: numpy.array, cv_split: str = 'time', n_splits: int = 5, param_dict: dict = None, x_tree=False, n_jobs=- 2)[source]¶

Perform randomize parameter search for randomforest regressor return the best estimator

Parameters

  • x_trn – 2D array of x data

  • y_trn – 2D np.array of y data

  • cv_split (optional) – if “time”. Use TimeSeriesSplit, which don’t shuffle the dataset.

  • n_splits (optional) – number of cross validation split [default:5]

  • params_dict (optional) – search parameter dictionary [default:None]

  • x_tree (optional) – if True, use ExtraTreesRegressor instead of RandomForestRegressor

  • n_jobs (optional) – number of CPU use [default:-1]

Returns: best estimator

src.models.train_model.feat_importance(model, x, y, x_cols, score=<function r2_score>, n_iter=20)[source]¶

Computes the feature importance by shuffle the data :param model: the model :param x: the training data :param y: target variable :param x_cols: name of the x columns :param metric: either r2_score of mean_squared_error

Returns: feature of importance pd.DataFrame

src.models.train_model.op_lag(dataset, model, split_ratio, lag_range=[2, 120], step_range=[1, 25])[source]¶

Search for the best lag parameters using skopt optimization

Parameters

  • dataset – dataset object

  • model – model object

  • split_ratio – list of split ratio

  • lag_range (optional) – min and max value of wind speed

  • step_range (optional) – min and max value of shift parameter

Return: fire_dict fire dictionary

src.models.train_model.reduce_cols(dataset, x_cols: list, to_drop: list, model, trn_i, val_i)[source]¶

Try droping the columns in to_drop. Keep track of the columns which can be remove from the model.

Parameters

  • dataset – dataset object

  • x_cols – current x columns

  • to_drop – data to drop

  • model – model object to fit and predict

  • trn_i – index in dataset.split_list for training data

  • val_i – index in dataset.split_list for validation data

Returns

fitted model x_cols: a list of new x_cols data

Return type

model

src.models.train_model.save_meta(meta_filename: str, model_meta)[source]¶

Save model_meta

Parameters

meta_filename – model_meta filename

Returns(optional): model meta dictionary

src.models.train_model.sk_op_fire(dataset, model, trn_index, val_index, wind_range: list = [2, 20], shift_range: list = [- 72, 72], roll_range: list = [24, 240], vis: bool = False, with_lag=False) → dict[source]¶

Search for the best fire parameter using skopt optimization

Parameters

  • dataset – dataset object

  • model – model object

  • trn_index – datetime index for training set

  • val_index – datetime index of validation set

  • wind_range (optional) – min and max value of wind speed

  • shift_range (optional) – min and max value of shift parameter

  • roll_range (optional) – min and max value of roll parameter

  • vis (optional) – if True, also plot the search space

  • with_lag (optional) – if True optimized the data with lag columns

Return: fire_dict fire dictionary

src.models.train_model.train_city_s1(city: str = 'Chiang Mai', pollutant: str = 'PM2.5', build=False, model=None, fire_dict=None, x_cols_org=[], lag_dict=None, x_cols=[])[source]¶

Training pipeline from process raw data, hyperparameter tune, and save model.

  1. If build True, build the raw data from files

  2. Process draw data into data using default values

  3. Optimization 1: optimize for the best randomforest model

  4. Optimization 2: remove unncessary columns

  5. Optimization 3: find the best fire feature

  6. Optimization 4: optimize for lag columns

  7. Optimization 5: drop unncessary lag columns

  8. Optimization 6: optimize for the best RF again

  9. Build pollution meta and save

Parameters

  • city – city name

  • pollutant (optional) – pollutant name

  • build (optional) – if True, also build the data

  • model (optional) –

  • op_fire (optional) –

  • x_cols_org (optional) –

  • lag_dict (optional) –

  • x_cols (optional) –

Returns

dataset model poll_meta(dict)

src.models.train_others module¶

src.models.train_others.do_knn_search(x_trn: numpy.array, y_trn: numpy.array, cv_split: str = 'time', n_splits: int = 5, param_dict: dict = None, x_tree=True)[source]¶

Perform randomize parameter search for KNN regressor return the best estimator

Parameters

  • x_trn – 2D array of x data

  • y_trn – 2D np.array of y data

  • cv_split (optional) – if “time”. Use TimeSeriesSplit, which don’t shuffle the data.

  • n_splits (optional) – number of cross validation split [default:5]

  • params_dict (optional) – search parameter dictionary [default:None]

  • x_tree (optional) – if True, use ExtraTreesRegressor instead of RandomForestRegressor

Returns: best estimator

src.models.train_others.do_ln_search(x_trn: numpy.array, y_trn: numpy.array, cv_split: str = 'time', n_splits: int = 5, param_dict: dict = None, ln_type='elastic', n_jobs=- 2)[source]¶

Perform randomize parameter search for linear regressir return the best estimator

Parameters

  • x_trn – 2D array of x data

  • y_trn – 2D np.array of y data

  • cv_split (optional) – if “time”. Use TimeSeriesSplit, which don’t shuffle the data.

  • n_splits (optional) – number of cross validation split [default:5]

  • params_dict (optional) – search parameter dictionary [default:None]

  • ln_type (optional) – type of linear regressor can be ‘elastic’, or lasso [default:’elastic’]

  • n_jobs (optional) – number of CPU use [default:-1]

Returns: best estimator

src.models.train_others.do_nn_search(xtrn: numpy.array, ytrn: numpy.array, xval, yval, n_jobs=- 2)[source]¶

Perform skopt optimization search for the best NN architecture.

Parameters

  • xtrn – normalized xtrn

  • ytrn – normalized ytrn

  • xval – normalized xval

  • ytrn – normalized yval

src.models.train_others.get_nn_model(input_shape: int, output_shape: int, num_layer: int, nn_size: int, act_fun: str, drop: float, lr: float, momentum: float)[source]¶

Get fully connected NN model according to the specified parameters

Parameters

  • input_shape – input dimension (according to the len of the columns)

  • output_shape – output dimension

  • num_layer – number of hidden layer can be 0

  • nn_size – number of neuron in one layer

  • act_fun – name of activation function

  • drop – dropout parameter

  • lr – optimizer learning rate

  • momentum – momentum parameter

src.models.train_others.op_lag_fire(dataset, model, split_ratio, lag_range=[2, 168], step_range=[1, 25], wind_range: list = [2, 20], shift_range: list = [- 72, 72], roll_range: list = [24, 240])[source]¶

Search for the best lag and fire parameters using skopt optimization

Parameters

  • dataset – dataset object

  • model – model object

  • split_ratio – list of split ratio

  • lag_range (optional) – min and max value of wind speed

  • step_range (optional) – min and max value of shift parameter

Return: fire_dict fire dictionary

src.models.train_others.train_city_s1_v2(city: str = 'Chiang Mai', pollutant: str = 'PM2.5', build=False, model=None, fire_dict=None, x_cols_org=[], lag_dict=None, x_cols=[])[source]¶

Training pipeline from process raw data, hyperparameter tune, and save model.

  1. If build True, build the raw data from files

  2. Process draw data into data using default values

  3. Optimization 1: optimize for the best randomforest model

  4. Optimization 2: remove unncessary columns

  5. Optimization 3: find the best fire feature

  6. Optimization 4: optimize for lag columns

  7. Optimization 5: drop unncessary lag columns

  8. Optimization 6: optimize for the best RF again

  9. Build pollution meta and save

Parameters

  • city – city name

  • pollutant (optional) – pollutant name

  • build (optional) – if True, also build the data

  • model (optional) –

  • op_fire (optional) –

  • x_cols_org (optional) –

  • lag_dict (optional) –

  • x_cols (optional) –

Returns

dataset model poll_meta(dict)

src.models.train_others.train_city_s2(city: str = 'Chiang Mai', pollutant: str = 'PM2.5', build=False, model=None, fire_dict=None, x_cols_org=[], lag_dict=None, x_cols=[])[source]¶

Training pipeline from process raw data, hyperparameter tune, and save model.

  1. If build True, build the raw data from files

  2. Process draw data into data using default values

  3. Optimization 1: optimize for the best NN model

  4. Build pollution meta and save

Args: city: city name pollutant(optional): pollutant name build(optional): if True, also build the data model(optional): x_cols_org(optional): lag_dict(optional):

Returns
